awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Learning in Networks: Performance Limits and Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
Many machine learning problems deal with networks that encode similarities or relationships among different objects, for which observational data may be limited in extent and noisy.  Learning the desired information requires highly efficient algorithms that can process large-scale network data and detect tenuous statistical signatures.  This project involves modeling large-scale networks and observations, devising learning algorithms, analyzing the performance of the algorithms, deriving bounds on the possible performance of best algorithms, and deploying theoretically-grounded algorithms to real network data.  The research aims to significantly advance the theoretical and algorithmic understanding of graphical inference and provide key enabling technologies for high-impact applications such as ordering of short DNA sub-sequences for genetic sequencing. Improvements in the ability to sequence DNA can accelerate the use of genomics with applications in health care. The associated mechanisms for broadening participation in computing include: (a) Explorations in computing and statistics for K-12 with broad participation; (b) Career and life skills guidance for graduate students at the Annual Allerton Conference on Communications, Control, and Computing; and (c) Mentoring female and minority students in research.

The research is grouped into four interrelated areas, ranging from inference problems for single graphs, to inference involving two graphs, in order  to study classification of graphs from general families: (a) learning community structure in dynamic graphs with heavy-tailed degree distribution, specifically, in a new variation of the Barabasi-Albert preferential attachment model; (b) recovering graphical structures beyond communities, including but not limited to recovery of hidden Hamiltonian cycles arising in a genetic sequencing problem and hidden matchings in bipartite graphs arising in a particle tracking problem; (c) matching two graphs to each other by identifying vertex correspondences, in particular, matching of perturbed versions of  Erdos-Renyi random graphs and  Barabasi-Albert preferential attachment graphs; and (d) learning properties of graphs using sampling, including sampling along random walks on graphs. Computationally efficient algorithms that estimate the number of both local structures (e.g., edges and triangles) and global structures are designed.   Network dynamics and subsampling, as well as inference of network structures that are not necessarily low rank or static, are addressed by employing techniques ranging from information theory, message passing, spectral and non-convex methods, and convex methods including linear, quadratic, and semi-definite relaxations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has made significant strides in enhancing our comprehension of information-theoretic and algorithmic aspects in machine learning tasks within networks. The primary focus has been on a class of planted assignment problems, involving random (weighted) graphs correlated with latent permutations. This class includes the planted matching problem (linear assignment), the graph matching problem (quadratic assignment), and planted Hamiltonian cycle problem (traveling salesperson problem). The project has successfully addressed new challenges arising from the absence of low-rank structures, leading to innovative analytic tools such as truncated second-moment methods, new types of I-MMSE formulas, and posterior sampling, and new algorithm designs. 

 

The Principal Investigator (PI) has achieved remarkable results by characterizing the sharp information-theoretic limits for recovering hidden permutations from graphical observations in both linear and quadratic assignment problems. Additionally, polynomial-time algorithms have been developed that achieve near-optimal performance, even up to the identified limits. A particularly notable breakthrough has been the resolution of the long-standing open problem of matching two correlated ER graphs with constant correlations for both dense and sparse graph regimes. This success was attained by counting a special family of trees called "chandeliers," proving their effectiveness whenever the correlation is above an explicit Otter’s tree counting threshold. Furthermore, the Otter’s threshold is conjectured to represent the computational limit in sparse graph regimes, supported by partial evidence from the low-degree polynomial method and analysis of local algorithms.

 

The project has also introduced a new type of spectral method for network alignment, applicable to general correlated graph models with diverse edge weight distributions. The proposed method computes the eigendecomposition of the two graph adjacency matrices and utilizes pairwise alignments between all eigenvectors of the first graph with those of the second to establish the matching. Moreover, the PI has derived sharp information-theoretic limits for matching two complete graphs with edge weights correlated through latent geometries. This extension facilitates random graph matching with independent edge weights to geometric models, bridging several literature streams encompassing planted matching, feature matching, Procrustes matching, and graph matching.

 

The theories and algorithms developed in this project have been successfully applied to address practical problems, including particle tracking, network de-anonymization, and 3D-shape matching in computer vision. These real-world applications underscore the versatility and relevance of the project's outcomes. The algorithms developed in this project have been made publicly accessible through the PI's website and Github, ensuring their availability and potential for broader adoption and use. 

 

The project has significantly contributed to educational goals by actively mentoring undergraduate, graduate students, and post-docs. Notably, one female Ph.D. student successfully defended her thesis under this research project and will commence her tenure-track assistant professor position after graduation. Additionally, a female post-doc has completed the proposed research under this project and initiated her tenure-track assistant professorship. Furthermore, research findings have been incorporated into a new Ph.D. class on Statistical Inference in Graphs and a short course on Recent Results in Planted Assignment Problems. The PI's efforts in organizing seminars, workshops, and invited sessions at various conferences have further disseminated the project's insights.

 

In summary, this project has significantly advanced the understanding of information-theoretic and algorithmic aspects in machine learning tasks within networks, particularly in the context of planted assignment problems. The innovative methods and tools, along with their practical applications, demonstrate the project's substantial impact on both theoretical and applied aspects of the field. Additionally, the project's educational contributions, through mentoring and course development, have fostered a diverse and talented pool of researchers to continue pushing the boundaries of knowledge in this domain.
